attributes.description:
Why this visualization works: It provides the actionable details behind an anomaly score. When the trend chart shows a spike, this table provides the 'who, what, and where,' listing the specific users, processes, and file paths that the ML job identified as anomalous. This is critical for efficient incident response and compliance verification.

How an analyst can use it: When investigating an anomaly, use this table to get immediate context. Sort by 'anomaly_score' to see the most impactful events. Look at the 'influencers.file.path' to see which critical files were changed, 'influencers.user.name' to see who made the change, and 'influencers.process.name' to see how the change was made. This information is key to determining if a change was authorized.
attributes.title: [CCI-001052] ML - Detailed System Change Anomalies

attributes.description: This section provides visualizations to help identify significant system changes that should trigger a risk assessment update, addressing CCI-001052. It tracks new vulnerabilities, critical configuration modifications, software changes, and high-severity security alerts. To perform a component-level compliance assessment, utilize the global filters at the top of the Kibana dashboard. Apply filters like 'host.name: <your_component_name>' to focus on a specific system. Observe the trends and individual events in the visualizations for any spikes or anomalies. A sudden increase in any of these areas indicates a change in the system's security state, which is a key trigger for initiating a risk assessment review as per organizational policy.
attributes.title: [CCI-001052] Risk Assessment Updates
attributes.visState: {"title":"[CCI-001052] Risk Assessment Updates","type":"markdown","aggs":[],"params":{"markdown":"# [CCI-001052] Risk Assessment Updates\n\n### Monitor for significant system changes.","fontSize":12,"openLinksInNewTab":false}}

attributes.description:
**Why this visualization works:** It provides the raw, granular data behind the trends. When a spike is observed in the trend chart, this table is used to see the specific events, including the host, user, process, and file involved. This level of detail is essential for the root cause analysis that informs a risk assessment. 

**How an analyst can use it:** After identifying a period of interest, use this table to investigate the individual change events. Sort by 'host.name' or 'user.name' to identify concentrated areas of activity. Examine the 'event.action', 'event.category', and 'file.path' fields to understand precisely what change occurred.

kibanaSavedObjectMeta.searchSourceJSON: {"query":{"language":"kuery","query":"(vulnerability.id:*) OR (event.category:file AND event.type:(change OR creation OR deletion) AND file.path:(*.conf OR *.ini OR *.xml OR *.yml OR *.yaml OR /etc/* OR /boot/* OR \"C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\config\\\\*\")) OR (event.category:package AND event.type:(installation OR deletion)) OR (event.category:iam AND event.type:(user_creation OR user_deletion OR group_creation OR group_deletion OR policy_update OR role_change)) OR (event.category:service AND event.type:(start OR stop OR modification)) OR (signal.rule.severity:(high OR critical))"},"filter":[],"indexRefName":"kibanaSavedObjectMeta.searchSourceJSON.index"}

attributes.title: [CCI-001052] Detailed System Change Events

attributes.description: This visualization displays the health status for CCI-001052 by monitoring the highest anomaly scores from its associated Machine Learning job, which detects anomalous rates of significant system changes. A high anomaly score indicates a significant deviation from the baseline, suggesting a risk assessment update is needed.
attributes.title: [CCI-001052] Risk Assessment Updates ML

attributes.description:
**Why this visualization works:** 
It offers a clear, at-a-glance breakdown of the *types* of significant changes occurring. This helps an analyst quickly prioritize their investigation by showing whether the majority of changes are related to vulnerabilities, file modifications, user accounts, or package installs. 

**How an analyst can use it:** 
Observe the distribution of change categories. A large slice for 'vulnerability' or 'iam' might be more critical than 'package', depending on context. Click on a slice of the donut to filter the dashboard and see the detailed events for only that category.

query.query: (vulnerability.id:*) OR (event.category:file AND event.type:(change OR creation OR deletion) AND file.path:(*.conf OR *.ini OR *.xml OR *.yml OR *.yaml OR /etc/* OR /boot/* OR "C:\\Windows\\System32\\config\\*")) OR (event.category:package AND event.type:(installation OR deletion)) OR (event.category:iam AND event.type:(user_creation OR user_deletion OR group_creation OR group_deletion OR policy_update OR role_change)) OR (event.category:service AND event.type:(start OR stop OR modification)) OR (signal.rule.severity:(high OR critical))

attributes.title: [CCI-001052] System Change Breakdown

attributes.description:
**Why this visualization works:** 
It provides a time-series view of significant system changes, broken down by category. This allows for a quick visual assessment of when and what type of changes are occurring, helping to spot unusual spikes that might warrant a risk assessment review. 

**How an analyst can use it:** 
Look for sudden increases in the overall trend or in a specific category of change. Hover over data points to see the exact count at a given time. Use the time range selector to narrow down suspicious periods where multiple significant changes occurred.

query.query: (vulnerability.id:*) OR (event.category:file AND event.type:(change OR creation OR deletion) AND file.path:(*.conf OR *.ini OR *.xml OR *.yml OR *.yaml OR /etc/* OR /boot/* OR "C:\\Windows\\System32\\config\\*")) OR (event.category:package AND event.type:(installation OR deletion)) OR (event.category:iam AND event.type:(user_creation OR user_deletion OR group_creation OR group_deletion OR policy_update OR role_change)) OR (event.category:service AND event.type:(start OR stop OR modification)) OR (signal.rule.severity:(high OR critical))

attributes.title: [CCI-001052] Significant System Change Trend

attributes.description:
This section provides Machine Learning (ML) powered visualizations to help assess compliance with CCI-001052, which is concerned with monitoring significant system changes (e.g., critical file modifications, package installations, IAM changes). These visualizations analyze anomaly scores from an ML job that detects unusual rates of these changes.

To perform a component-level compliance assessment, utilize the global filters at the top of the Kibana dashboard. Apply filters such as 'influencers.host.name: <your_component_name>' or 'influencers.user.name: <user_name>' to focus your analysis. The ML model learns the baseline of normal administrative and system activity. A high anomaly score (e.g., 75 or above) can reveal unauthorized or malicious changes that might otherwise blend in with routine activities, such as an attacker installing rogue software or altering critical configuration files.
